answers.answer: How are you? Diabetic neuropathy is a peripheral nerve disorder caused by diabetes. The symptoms are often slight at first and may go unnoticed for a long time. Numbness, pain, or tingling in the feet, or legs may, after several years, lead to weakness in the muscles of the feet. The goal of treating diabetic neuropathy is to relieve discomfort and prevent further tissue damage. It is important to bring blood sugar levels under control by diet and medication. Another important part of treatment involves taking special care of the feet. It would be good to discuss your worries with your doctor and he may give you proper medications for pain management.I hope this helps. Take care and keep us posted.

question: I have never been told I am a diabetic yet around 2000 I began having left foot pain.  It would allow me with good shoes to be on it 5 hours a day.  I was inactive.  but worked verry hard.  I then had my mitral valve replaced and in an effort to come back to work I worked my way up to 10 mile walks after 4 months.  I then had a right hemisphere stroke.  Again I walked up to 4 miles and had recovered well from the stroke when my foot problem got so bad it hurt sitting or standing and now the pain is spreadig up the leg.  mri's rule out foot problems and back problems.  my dr. says it is neuropathy.  this pain is so bad I can hardly walk through the room.  my dr. is no help to me?
title: my foot hurts
